repnme.cdata!:
Malawi - First, Second and Third Fiscal
            Restructuring and Deregulation and Second and Third Fiscal
            Restructuring and Deregulation Technical Assistance Programs

abstracts.cdata!:
The First Fiscal Restructuring and
            Deregulation Program (FRDP 1)had the following ratings:
            unsatisfactory outcome, likely sustainability, modest
            institutional development impact, satisfactory Bank
            performance, and unsatisfactory Borrower performance. The
            Second Fiscal Restructuring and Deregulation Program (FRDP
            11) had the following ratings: unsatisfactory outcome,
            likely sustainability, modest institutional development
            impact, unsatisfactory Bank performance The First Fiscal
            Restructuring and Deregulation Program (FRDP I), and
            unsatisfactory Borrower performance. The Third Fiscal
            Restructuring and Deregulation Program (FRDP 111) had the
            following ratings: highly unsatisfactory outcome, unlikely
            sustainability, negligible institutional development impact,
            highly unsatisfactory Bank performance, and highly
            unsatisfactory Borrower performance. The Second Fiscal
            Restructuring and Deregulation Program TA (FRDP 11TA) had
            the following ratings: moderately satisfactory outcome,
            likely sustainability, modest institutional development
            impact, satisfactory Bank performance, and satisfactory
            Borrower performance. The Third Fiscal Restructuring and
            Deregulation Program TA (FRDP 111TA) had the following
            ratings: unsatisfactory outcome, unevaluable sustainability,
            modest institutional development impact, unsatisfactory Bank
            performance, and satisfactory Borrower performance. The
            experience in these projects highlights the following
            lessons: (a) incentives within the Bank can motivate unwise
            lending; (b) the region's macroeconomic assessments
            need to have greater realism and consistency; (c)
            policy-based lending in an unstable macroeconomic
            environment is unwise; (d) in promoting reform, the Bank
            needs to take account of the incentives that a program
            creates; and (e) the Bank should structure lending to Malawi
            with more earmarked, targeted aid, and tighter fiduciary controls.

repnme.cdata!:
Malawi - Fiscal Restructuring and
            Deregulation Program Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is adjudged
            satisfactory overall, and project sustainability is likely.
            Both World Bank and Borrower performances were found to be
            satisfactory. Key lessons learned include the following: The
            project demonstrates the synergy betwee macroeconomic
            stabilization and structural reforms: reaping the full
            benefits of structural reform depends heavily on fiscal
            discipline and avoidance of inflationary pressures. Careful
            and extensive preparation, including a dtrong background of
            economic and sector work, extensive collaboration with
            government, consultation with stakeholders and coordination
            with other suppliers of external assistance, and is a
            necessary but not sufficient condition for execution of
            complex adjustment. Restructuring of the government, the
            civil service and the budget must have political leadership
            and be based on decisions about the future role of the
            public sector. Attempting to introduce a new system of
            expenditure prioritization and budget allocation by
            superimposing it on an existing, inadequate budgeting system
            is not likely to be successful. Including technical
            assistance components in adjustment operations invariably
            results in closing well after disbursement of
            performancerelated tranches, and delays ICR preparation,
            thus reducing the ICR's influence on shaping future
            operations. This can be remedied by making the technical
            assistance a separate credit.

repnme.cdata!:
Malawi - Fiscal Restructuring and
            Deregulation Program Project

abstracts.cdata!:
To assist Malawi to attain its economic
            objectives and succeed in alleviating the country's
            pervasive poverty problem, the Fiscal Restructuring and
            Deregulation Program Project will aim to: 1) prioritize,
            protect and, where necessary, expand inter-sectoral and
            intra-sectoral allocations to the social sectors on a
            sustainable basis while staying within the overall fiscal
            framework now being monitored under the IMF's Enhanced
            Structural Adjustment Facility (ESAF) program; and 2)
            accelerate the consolidation of structural measures already
            initiated by the government of Malawi under previous
            adjustment operations. This will include complete removal of
            remaining pricing and marketing constraints on smallholder
            agriculture, and removal of the biding constraints to
            broad-based private sector entry and development. The
            project will have the following components: 1) fiscal
            restructuring which involves public spending reorientation,
            restoring of fiscal discipline, civil service reform, and
            tax and tariff reforms; 2) deregulation of agricultural
            policies including access to land, access to cash crops,
            access to inputs, access to markets, and access to economic
            transport; and 3) deregulation of private sector development
            policies comprising investment promotion, deconcentration
            and privatization.
